revision.text:
{{Infobox military unit |unit_name = 9th Guards Army |dates = 1945–1946 |country = {{flag|Soviet Union}} |branch = [[Red Army]] |type = Combined arms |size = 3 rifle corps |command_structure = [[2nd Ukrainian Front]]
[[3rd Ukrainian Front]] |battles = [[World War II]] *[[Vienna Offensive]] *[[Prague Offensive]] |notable_commanders = [[Vasily Glagolev]] }}The '''9th Guards Army''' was a [[field army]] of the [[Red Army]] during [[World War II]], which fought in the [[Vienna Offensive]] and the [[Prague Offensive]] at the end of the war. The army was formed in January 1945 and included airborne divisions converted into infantry. Postwar, the army headquarters became [[Soviet airborne]] headquarters. == History == === Formation === The 9th Guards Army was formed on 5 January 1945 under the command of [[Vasily Glagolev]] as directed by the [[Stavka]] directive of 18 December 1944.{{Cite web|title = 9-я ГВАРДЕЙСКАЯ АРМИЯ|url = http://bdsa.ru/%25D0%25B3%25D0%25B2%25D0%25B0%25D1%2580%25D0%25B4%25D0%25B5%25D0%25B9%25D1%2581%25D0%25BA%25D0%25B8%25D0%25B5-%25D0%25B0%25D1%2580%25D0%25BC%25D0%25B8%25D0%25B8/2772-9|website = bdsa.ru|accessdate = 2015-11-25|trans-title = 9th Guards Army|language = Russian}} It was formed from the headquarters of the [[7th Army (Soviet Union)|7th Army]] and the [[Separate Airborne Army]].{{Sfn|Feskov et al|2003|p=21}} It was composed of the [[37th Guards Airborne Corps|37th]], [[38th Guards Airborne Corps|38th]] and [[39th Guards Airborne Corps|39th Guards Rifle Corps]]. In February, the army was transferred to southeastern [[Hungary]], near [[Budapest]]. It became part of the [[2nd Ukrainian Front]] on 27 February to participate in the Vienna Offensive.{{Sfn|Erickson|1999|p=510}} === Vienna and Prague Offensives === [[File:Vienna Operations.jpg|thumb|Soviet troops during the Vienna Offensive]] It was transferred to the [[3rd Ukrainian Front]] on 9 March. Between 8 and 14 March the army was moved from the [[Kecskemét|Kecslemet]] area across the [[Danube]] into the [[Zámoly]] sector, replacing the [[4th Guards Army]].{{Sfn|Glantz|2012|pp=517–520}} Between 16 March and 15 April, the army fought in the Vienna Offensive. Units of the army broke through German defences north of [[Székesfehérvár]] in conjunction with the [[4th Guards Army]]. Advancing in the left flank and rear of the [[6th SS Panzer Army]], the 9th Guards Army broke through other German units between [[Lake Balaton]] and [[Velence]]. For the assault on Vienna, the army's 39th Guards Rifle Corps would follow the attack of the [[6th Guards Army]] in the southwestern sector. The 38th Guards Rifle Corps was to cut the Vienna-Linz road and use two divisions to protect the attack from the west. The 37th Guards Rifle Corps protected the assault force's left flank. The 9th Guards Army attacked the northwestern road out of [[Vienna]] in conjunction with the [[6th Guards Tank Army]] and broke German resistance in early April. On 13 April, the army helped capture Vienna.{{Sfn|Erickson|1999|p=549}} The army then fought in the [[Prague Offensive]], where it captured [[Znojmo]] on 8 May in conjunction with the [[7th Guards Army (Soviet Union)|7th Guards Army]]. It also captured [[Retz]] and [[Písek]], ending the war on the [[Elbe]].{{Cite web|title = 9-я гвардейская армия|url = http://samsv.narod.ru/Arm/ag09/arm.html|website = samsv.narod.ru|accessdate = 2015-11-25|language = Russian|trans-title = 9th Guards Army}} === Postwar === The army had its headquarters in [[Szolnok]] from July 1945 to June 1946 and was part of the [[Central Group of Forces]].{{Cite web|title = 9th Guards Combined Arms Army|url = http://www.ww2.dk/new/army/armies/9gvoa.htm|website = www.ww2.dk|accessdate = 2015-11-25|last = Holm|first = Michael}} In 1946, its headquarters became the [[Soviet airborne]] headquarters and its corps were converted into airborne divisions.{{sfn|1=Feskov et al|2=2013|p=234}} == Composition == The army was composed of the following units in February 1945.[[Combat composition of the Soviet Army]], 1 February 1945 * [[37th Guards Airborne Corps|37th Guards Rifle Corps]] ** [[98th Guards Rifle Division]] ** [[99th Guards Rifle Division]] ** [[103rd Guards Rifle Division]] * [[38th Guards Airborne Corps|38th Guards Rifle Corps]] ** [[104th Guards Rifle Division]] ** [[105th Guards Rifle Division]] ** [[106th Guards Rifle Division]] * [[39th Guards Airborne Corps|39th Guards Rifle Corps]] ** [[100th Guards Rifle Division]] ** [[107th Guards Rifle Division]] ** [[114th Guards Rifle Division]] *35th Guards Gun Artillery Brigade *36th Anti-Tank Artillery Brigade *319th Guards Mortar Regiment *321st Guards Mortar Regiment *322nd Guards Mortar Regiment *1513th Self-Propelled Artillery Regiment *1523rd Self-Propelled Artillery Regiment *1524th Self-Propelled Artillery Regiment *15th Engineer-Sapper Brigade *7th Separate Flamethrower Battalion == References == * {{Cite book|title=Stalin's War with Germany: The road to Berlin|last=Erickson|first=John|publisher=Yale University Press|year=1999|isbn=9780300078138|location=New Haven|ref=harv|orig-year=1983}} * {{Cite book|url=http://militera.lib.ru/h/0/pdf/feskov_vi01.pdf|title=Красная Армия в победах и поражениях 1941–1945 гг.|last=Feskov|first=V.I.|last2=Kalashnikov|first2=K.A.|last3=Golikov|first3=V.I.|publisher=Tomsk University Press|year=2003|isbn=5751116240|location=Tomsk|pages=|language=Russian|trans-title=The Red Army in the victories and defeats 1941–1945|ref={{SfnRef|Feskov et al|2003}}|via=}} * {{Cite book|title=Вооруженные силы СССР после Второй Мировой войны: от Красной Армии к Советской|last=Feskov|first=V.I.|last2=Golikov|first2=V.I.|last3=Kalashnikov|first3=K.A.|last4=Slugin|first4=S.A.|publisher=Scientific and Technical Literature Publishing|year=2013|isbn=9785895035306|location=Tomsk|language=Russian|trans-title=The Armed Forces of the USSR after World War II: From the Red Army to the Soviet: Part 1 Land Forces|ref={{sfnRef|Feskov et al|2013}}}} * {{Cite book|title=Soviet Military Deception in the Second World War|last=Glantz|first=David M.|publisher=Routledge|year=2012|isbn=9781136287657|location=Abingdon-on-Thames|ref=harv|orig-year=1989|via=}} {{Armies of the Soviet Army}} [[Category:Field armies of the Soviet Union|G09]]
